results.title: Don's Party
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Phillip Adams and Art House Productions
results.brief_description: Bruce Beresford’s classic Australian comedy exposes Australian social mores in the suburbs. Don and Kath have invited a group of friends to celebrate what they believe will be a Labor Party victory on Election night. The night begins happily enough until the guests receive the news that Labor is losing. Old enmities erupt as hostilities break out amongst the guests as the party disintegrates into an alcoholic disaster. Cast includes Ray Barrett, Graham Kennedy, John Hargreaves, Graeme Blundell, Jeanie Drynan and Clare Binney.

results.title: Ka-wayawayama: Aeroplane Dance
results.creator_credit: Jan Wositzky, Trevor Graham, Christina Pozzan and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Records the story of “Ka-wayawayama” or “Aeroplane Dance” of the Yanuwa people of the Borroloola area in the Northern Territory. The dance was created after an American “Liberator” bomber crashed in the area in 1942, after a mission in the South-west Pacific. Re-creates the plight of the flight crew in their trek across inhospitable terrain across the Gulf of Carpentaria and the search for the lost crew.

results.title: Behind the menu
results.brief_description: A survey of the use of gas in commercial cooking and industrial establishments. The film includes glimpses of what happens “behind the menu” at establishments like the Menzies Hotel, The Royal Melbourne Hospital, the canteen at General Motors and a biscuit factory.

results.title: Rats in the Ranks
results.creator_credit: Robin Anderson, Bob Connolly, Arundel Productions, Film Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: A behind-the-scenes look at political manoeuvering during the Mayoral elections for the Leichardt Council. Incumbent Larry Hand, while popular with the voters is not so popular with the Council.

constellations_other.name: Bob Connolly
constellations_other.description: Australian audiences just can't seem to get enough of exploring local governments, bureaucracy and politics, whether that's through documentaries or biting social satire.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin Anderson, Bob Connolly, Arundel Productions, Film Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.description: A behind-the-scenes look at political manoeuvering during the Mayoral elections for the Leichardt Council. Incumbent Larry Hand, while popular with the voters is not so popular with the Council. In the Mayoral elections, the Council not the citizens vote, so Hand and his opposition engage in a battle of political tactics including calling in favours, backstabbing and media leaks. Gripping real-life drama with a knuckle-biting climax.
description_for_label: A behind-the-scenes look at political manoeuvering during the Mayoral elections for the Leichardt Council. Gripping real-life drama with a knuckle-biting climax.

results.title: Doc: a Portrait of Herbert Vere Evatt, 1894-1965
results.creator_credit: Pat Fiske, David McKnight, Denise Haslem, Film Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Known as “the Doc”, Evatt was an idealist, internationalist, a lawyer and a politician. He was the only Australian elected as President of the United Nations (1948) and the decisions he handed down as a High Court Judge had lasting effects on the course of Australian political history. Evatt fought to defeat an attempt to ban the Communist Party, only to find that his own party, the Australian Labor Party was deeply divided on the issue and his contentious role in 1950’s politics overshadows his many notable achievements. This excellent documentary blends commentary, newsreel footage and interviews with historians, family and public figures to offer a rare and moving insight into the life of one of Australia’s most notable political figures.

results.title: On the Beach
results.creator_credit: Stanley Kramer, United Artists Corporation and Lomitas Productions
results.brief_description: On the Beach is one of the most celebrated anti-nuclear films in motion picture history. Based on the novel by Nevil Shute, it is the story of US Naval commander Dwight Towers, who is sent to assist Australian authorities after the rest of the world has been devastated by a nuclear holocaust.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Stanley Kramer, United Artists Corporation and Lomitas Productions
results.description: ‘On the Beach’ is one of the most celebrated anti-nuclear films in motion picture history. Based on the novel by Nevil Shute, it is the story of US Naval commander Dwight Towers, who is sent to assist Australian authorities after the rest of the world has been devastated by a nuclear holocaust. Towers must attempt to save a small group of survivors as impending doom approaches.

results.title: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert
results.creator_credit: Stephan Elliott, Michael Hamlyn, Al Clark, Specific Films and Latent Image
results.brief_description: When drag queen Anthony (Hugo Weaving) takes his act on the road with fellow cross-dresser Adam (Guy Pearce) and transsexual Bernadette (Terence Stamp). In their colorful bus, Priscilla, the three performers travel across the Australian desert performing for enthusiastic crowds and homophobic locals.

constellations_primary.name: Joy of drag
constellations_primary.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Gender bending larrikins
constellations_other.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

constellations_other.name: Hiding in plain sight
constellations_other.description: This print of upside-down heads is an early optical illusion featuring hidden characters. Movie studios have continued the tradition of playing with perspective in the bold designs, vivid colours and hidden meanings of film posters.

constellations_other.name: Dance sequins
constellations_other.description: Looking at dance, ballroom, the Glitter Trilogy and the Red Curtain Trilogy.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as Character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

recommendations.quote: The film's three leads have all swapped fabulous frocks for villainous outfits in superhero films. Terrance Stamp was Zod in Superman 2, Hugo Weaving was Red Skull in Captain America: The First Avenger and Guy Pearce was Aldrich Killian in Iron Man 3.

results.title_for_label: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephan Elliott, Michael Hamlyn, Al Clark, Specific Films and Latent Image
results.description:
This incredibly successful Australian comedy traces the adventures of three Sydney drag queens who travel through the Australian outback in order to perform their exuberant act in Alice Springs.

On their journey through the desert, on a bus christened Priscilla, they encounter both friendship and enmity from the small bush communities. Guy Pearce is excellent as the youngest drag queen who has a tough mouth but a lot to learn about the world, while Hugo Weaving is moving as a man who must reveal the truth of his homosexuality to his son. Terence Stamp is unforgettable as the transgendered Bernice and the loving relationship that develops between Stamp and Bill Hunter’s outback “bloke” is very tender and touching.

Full of humour, colour and bizarre costumes for which the film won an Academy Award, Priscilla is a wickedly entrancing family movie which shows that not only Australian cities but the mythical Australian bush has been affected and changed by ethnic and sexual multiculturalism. The soundtrack is full of great drag disco classics from ‘I Will Survive’ and ‘Go West’ to the more recent ‘Finally’ and ‘Save the Best for Last’.
description_for_label:

results.title: On our selection
results.creator_credit: Ken G. Hall, Bert Bailey and Bailey Film Productions
results.brief_description: The first Dad and Dave ‘talkie’ based on the long running stage hit that was derived from the stories of Steele Rudd. The play was a huge success with Depression audiences and in his screen adaptation, Ken Hall stressed the characters’ abilities to fight back against adversity. An early Australian classic.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken G. Hall, Bert Bailey and Bailey Film Productions

results.title: A Handful of dust
results.creator_credit: Charles Sturridge, Derek Granger, Stagescreen and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Tony and Brenda Last (James Wilby and Kristin Scott Thomas) appear to be the perfect married ccouple - with money, position, a great country house and an adored son, John Andrew. When Tony inadvertently invites John Beaver (Rupert Graves), an idle and penniless young socialite, to stay for the weekend, he sets in motion a series of events which drastically disrupts the course of all their lives. Brenda drifts into an affair with the worthless Mr. Beaver, with disastrous consequences, particularly for Tony, who remains unaware of Brenda’s betrayal until the tragic death of their young son. As Brenda leaves home to take up a precarious life with her lover in London. Tony sets sail with an eccentric explorer on an expedition to the South American rain forests. Lost in the jungle and stricken by fever, Tony is rescued from death by the eccentric Mr. Todd (Alec Guinness) with unexpected and sinister results.

results.title: Blackfellas
results.creator_credit: James Ricketson, Penny Chapman, David Rapsey and Barron Films
results.brief_description: But we’re your people. Doug Dooligan has lost count of the number of times he’s heard that phrase. Nineteen years old and on parole all he wants to do is get on with his life, away from the influence of his best friend Floyd “Pretty Boy” Davies. Doug wants to get a job, save some money and buy back his father’s property, Yetticup, the land of his people’s Dreaming. Floyd wants his old partner in crime to join him in “bigger and better things”. Floyd thinks Doug’s decision to go straight means that he is giving up on his “blackfella” lifestyle and being a “whitefella”. Doug is half white and is torn between his love for Floyd and his family obligations. The pressures of friendship, family, identity and blackfella versus whitefella lifestyles, almost jeopardise Doug’s chances of achieving his dream. He goes back to his old ways, but unexpectedly the tables turn and it is Floyd who acts to save Doug’s dream, and give him hope for the future. BLACKFELLAS is based on the book “Day of the dog” by Archie Weller, a Perth writer who grew up with the Nyoongah people from the Perth area and James Ricketson, the writer/director of BLACKFELLAS, consulted extensively with the Nyoongah community during the development of the script. It is a moving and powerful study of Aboriginal society which is shown from an insider’s perspective, producing a sensitive and compassionate drama. Awards: Winner, Feature Film Category, Human Rights Awards, 1993; Western Australian Premier’s Literary Award, 1993; Nominated, Best Achievement in Direction and Best Performance by an Actor in a Leading Role, Australian Film Institute Awards, 1993; Winner, Best Screenplay Adapted from Another Source and Best Performance by an Actor in a Supporting Role, Australian Film Institute Awards, 1993
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Ricketson, Penny Chapman, David Rapsey and Barron Films
